awd_titl_txt: SCC-CIVIC-PG Track A: Novel Fuel-Flexible Combustion to Enable Ultra-Clean and Efficient Waste-to-Renewable Energy in Changing Climate
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to simultaneously address the two priorities defined by the City of Waco (Waco) including limited surface area for landfills, and energy demand especially during extreme weather due to global warming.  Currently, converting Municipal Solid Waste (MSW) in landfills to fuels for energy results in very viscous oils that are hard to burn efficiently and cleanly.  We propose a process that will operate efficiently and cleanly regardless of the MSW composition with minimal pre- and post-processing to help decrease surface area needed for landfills, provide resilient energy and help combat greenhouse gas emissions (GHGs) that contribute to climate change both from combustion and from landfill emissions.  Carbon dioxide (CO2), other pollutant emissions such as particulate matters, unburned hydrocarbons, nitrogen oxides from combustion significantly contribute to global warming.  Additionally, methane is the second most important GHG with a 20-year global warming potential ~83 times higher than CO2, and organic MSW in landfills is a significant methane emission source. This project will therefore simultaneously decrease GHGs from landfills and recover energy in the waste using the novel waste-to-energy combustor with near-zero emissions for renewable power and heat.  Success of this novel concept will therefore decrease local waste treatment burdens and boost energy resilience in a changing climate. The scalability and multi-fuel capability will help satisfy energy needs of underserved groups, and the communities at large under an extreme weather event.  

This project will develop a multi-fuel pilot combustor that can cleanly convert local MSW to liquid and gaseous fuels and combust them with minimal postprocessing.  Challenges to clean and efficient combustion of waste-based fuels addressed here are (1) accommodating variations in fuel composition and properties and (2) efficient and low emission combustion of the highly viscous oils/condensates fuels.  Objectives of Stage 1 include (1) preselecting a waste-to-fuels process informed by Waco and (2) demonstrating efficient combustion of waste-fuels generated in (1).  The preselection defines the waste-to-fuel path and key parts for the fuel-flexible pilot combustor will be tested on site at the Waco facility in Stage 2. Scaling analysis will also be examined in Stage 2 based on example community profiles in partnership with Waco and Baylor’s School of Social Work. In addition to conventional publications, results will also be disseminated through informal education at Baylor’s Mayborn Museum through the NSF Portal-to-the-Public program, and collaboration with Waco and Mission Waco Urban Reap, and transferred to commercialization through Baylor’s lab-to-market team.

This project is in response to the Civic Innovation Challenge program—Track A. Living in a changing climate: pre-disaster action around adaptation, resilience, and mitigation—and is a collaboration between NSF, the Department of Homeland Security, and the Department of Energy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF CIVIC Stage-1 project aims to partner with the City of Waco and significant local stakeholders to quickly develop a multi-fuel near-zero-emission pilot combustor that can cleanly convert liquid and gaseous fuels with distinct properties generated from local waste into renewable energy with minimal processing. Existing landfill flares destruct methane to mitigate global warming but, due to incomplete combustion, these flares emit other pollutants which both harm human health and contribute to greenhouse emissions. Furthermore, existing combustion systems have low-fuel flexibility, requiring complex pre- and post- processing of fuels, hindering the ability to use a wide variety of waste to create renewable energy. This Baylor University and City of Waco (CW) collaboration pilot project is to enable clean landfill flare and clean waste-to-energy (WtE) with high fuel flexibility, near-zero emissions, and high resilience. Consequently, this project strongly supports the sustainability and resilience strategic priorities that the City of Waco developed after the power outages during 2021 TX Winter Storm Uri. The Stage-1 panning project has prepared the team with seamless collaboration with local communities, deeper and refined scope, and identified technical and social solutions to rapidly promise the aim in a changing climate. The specific objectives of the proposed work in Stage 1 include (1) preselecting a path of waste-to-fuels per the priority and availability of the City of Waco and the feasibility in the short-period of Stage 2; (2) preselecting novel fuel-air mixers for co-combustion of biogas-bio-oils generated from the waste-fuel path in (1). The preselection has refined and narrowed the waste-to-fuel path and key parts for the fuel-flexible pilot combustor tests on site at the CW facility.

Intellectual Merit

The main intellectual merits of the Stage-1 outcomes are: (1) the identified novel fuel-flexible combustion concepts. They include (a) novel components of fuel injection and mixers for ultra-clean consumption of various gaseous and liquid fuels (e.g., landfill gas and others such as biocrudes) derived from varieties of waste sources; (b) novel external combustion engines with the novel “drop-in” components in (a) to enable ultra-efficient clean WtE with minimal pre and post processing and maximum cost-effectiveness; (2) new knowledge on global flame structure of straight viscous oils and co-combustion with gaseous fuels (methane, the main component of LFG) made up per the key components for the selected waste-fuel path; (3) identified high-fidelity modeling on the atmosphere and the global warming locally to nationally using the emission data from the proposed WtE combustor; (4) identified approaches to quantify economic benefits with energy resilience and equity for the proposed technology in Stage 2 if awarded.

Broader Impacts

Success of the proposed fuel-flexible waste-to-energy combustor will enable clean and efficient waste-to-energy with minimal fuel postprocessing. The community-based system can provide high energy resilience for local power and heat during extreme weather by global warming. It mitigates methane emission from waste (eg. landfill) and significantly alleviates its larger and longer global warming (GW) potential than CO2. Instead, the proposed approach will convert it to renewable energy to further cut the current fossil fuel consumption that promotes GW. The Stage-1 project has directly involved student researchers from various levels and background and equipped them with solid fundamentals, and sustainable minds to be future leaders impacting more. The knowledge gained are to be integrated in the PIs’ combustion and renewable energy courses for broader impacts on many students to deliver future workforce for renewable energy areas. The project bridges the in-lab fundamental research to community applications, leveraging impacts of novel technologies. Implantation of the ultimate combustor in other communities will leverage the country’s waste-to-energy industry, providing new job opportunities. Working with the Baylor Broader Impact specialists in Stage 1, we also plan to broadly educate more undergraduate and graduate students by continuously integrating Stage-2 results in the renewable energy relevant curriculum and educates K-12 students and the public on sustainability and resilience through designed activities and exhibits at the Baylor Mayborn Museum and a minority-serving high school. It also engages local minority communities such as Centra-Texas Hispanic Chamber of Commerce who suffered from recent climate events and those attending the Green Communities Conference of the Waco Sustainability Network. Through Baylor/CW partnership embedded in the CW’s sustainability strategy, the pilot project will first benefit the local communities and the society at large by transferring to other cities via Baylor’s unique Lab-to-Market program.
